text: {{Infobox writer | image = Galway Kinnell Grindstone Cafe Lyndonville VT March 2013.jpg | caption = Reading poetry at Beatnik Party Grindstone Cafe, Lyndonville, Vermont March 16, 2013 | name = Galway Kinnell | pseudonym = | birth_date = | birth_place = Providence, Rhode Island | death_date = | death_place = Sheffield, Vermont | occupation = Poet | nationality = American | awards = | website = }} Galway Kinnell (February 1, 1927 â€“ October 28, 2014) was an American poet. For his 1982 Selected Poems, he won the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry and split the National Book Award for Poetry with Charles Wright. From 1989 to 1993 he was poet laureate for the state of Vermont. He was inspired by the works of Walt Whitman. His best-loved poems are "St. Francis and the Sow" and "After Making Love We Hear Footsteps". He also in favour with civil rights movement against racial segregation and opposed Vietman War. Kinnell died in Sheffield, Vermont from leukemia, aged 87. == Related pages == *List of poets from North America ==References== Category:Pulitzer Prize winners Category:1927 births Category:2014 deaths Category:Deaths from leukemia Category:American poets Category:Writers from Providence, Rhode Island
